doc_description: The document is a comprehensive guide on MIL-STD-1686C, detailing the establishment and implementation of an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) Control Program to protect sensitive electronic components, with specific requirements for classification, handling, training, and quality assurance.

structure.title: Preface
structure.text:
NOT MEASUREMENT
                                                                                                 SENSITIVE
MIL-STD-1686C
 25 October 1995
SUPERSEDINGMIL-STD-1686B31 December 1992
DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
STANDARD PRACTICE
ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE CONTROL PROGRAM FOR 
PROTECTION OF ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC PARTS,
ASSEMBLIES AND EQUIPMENT (EXCLUDING
ELECTRICALLY INITIATED EXPLOSIVE DEVICES)
AMSC N/A AREA RELI
MIL-STD-1686C
iiFOREWORD
1.  This standard is approved for use by all Departments and
Agencies of the Department of Defense.
2.  This standard covers the establishment and
implementation of an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) ControlProgram for any activity that designs, tests, inspects, services,manufactures, processes, assembles, installs, packages, labels,or otherwise handles electrical or electronic parts, assembliesand equipment susceptible to damage by static electricity.  Thisdocument provides control program requirements for ESD sensitive(ESDS) items susceptible to damage from discharges of up to15,999 volts Human Body Model (HBM) Classes 1-3.  This standarddoes not apply to electrically initiated explosive devices orpart level design requirements.  MIL-HDBK-263 provides additionalinformation relative to the implementation of this standard.
3.  Electrostatic charges are generated by the relative
motion, physical separation of materials or flow of solids,liquids, or gases.  Common sources of ESD include personnel,items made of common plastics, and processing equipment.  ESD candamage parts by direct contact with a charged source or bycharges induced from electrostatic fields.  Examples of ESDSparts are micro-circuits, discrete semiconductors, thick and thinfilm resistors, hybrid devices and piezoelectric crystals.
4.  Beneficial comments (recommendations, additions,
deletions) and any pertinent data which may be of use inimproving this document should be addressed to:  Commander, NavalSea Systems Command, SEA 03R42,  2531 Jefferson Davis Highway,Arlington, VA 22242-5160, by using the Standardization DocumentImprovement Proposal (DD Form 1426) appearing at the end of thisdocument or by letter.
structure.summary:
The partial document is a section of MIL-STD-1686C, a standard practice issued by the Department of Defense on October 25, 1995, superseding MIL-STD-1686B. The main points covered include:

1. **Purpose and Scope**: The standard outlines the establishment and implementation of an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) Control Program to protect electrical and electronic parts, assemblies, and equipment susceptible to static electricity damage. It applies to activities involving the design, testing, handling, and processing of ESD sensitive (ESDS) items.

2. **ESD Sensitivity**: The document specifies control program requirements for ESDS items that can be damaged by discharges up to 15,999 volts (Human Body Model Classes 1-3).

3. **Sources of ESD**: Electrostatic charges can be generated by the motion, separation of materials, or flow of solids, liquids, or gases. Common sources include personnel, plastics, and processing equipment.

4. **Examples of ESDS Parts**: Micro-circuits, discrete semiconductors, thick and thin film resistors, hybrid devices, and piezoelectric crystals are mentioned as examples of ESDS parts.

5. **Feedback and Improvement**: The document encourages feedback and suggestions for improvement, providing contact information for submissions.

11.  SCOPE
1.1  Purpose.  The purpose of this standard is to establish
comprehensive requirements for an ESD control program to minimize
the effects of ESD on parts, assemblies, and equipment.  Aneffective ESD control program will increase reliability anddecrease both maintenance actions and lifetime costs.  Thisstandard shall be tailored for various types of acquisitions.
1.2  Scope.  This standard defines the performance
requirements for an ESD control program for electrical and
electronic parts, assemblies, and equipment, susceptible todamage from ESD.  Electrically initiated explosive devices andpart level design are excluded from these requirements.  Thisstandard covers identification, testing, classification, assemblyand equipment design criteria, protected areas, handlingprocedures, training, marking of hardware, protective coveringand packaging, and provides for quality assurance requirements,audits and reviews.
1.3  Application.  This standard shall apply to Government
activities and contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, and
vendors.  When this standard is applied to Government activitiesthe term "contractor" shall be replaced with "Governmentactivity" as appropriate.
2.  APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS
2.1  General.  The documents listed in this section are
specified in sections 3,4, and 5 of this standard.  This section
does not include documents cited in other sections of thisstandard or recommended for additional information or asexamples.  While every effort has been made to ensure thecompleteness of this list, document users are cautioned that theymust meet all specified requirements documents cited in sections3,4, and 5 of this standard, whether or not they are listed.
2.2  Government documents.
2.2.1  Specifications, standards, and handbooks.  The
following standards and handbook form a part of this document to
the extent specified herein.  Unless otherwise specified, theissues of these documents are those listed in the issue of theDepartment of Defense Index of Specifications and Standards
structure.summary:
The partial document discusses the military standard MIL-STD-1686C, which focuses on the establishment and implementation of an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) Control Program. Key points include:

1. **Approval and Scope**: The standard is approved for use by all Departments and Agencies of the Department of Defense and covers activities related to handling electrical or electronic parts susceptible to ESD damage.
2. **ESD Sources and Damage**: Electrostatic charges can be generated by various sources such as personnel, plastics, and processing equipment, and can damage ESD-sensitive parts like micro-circuits and semiconductors.
3. **Document Structure**: The document includes sections on scope, applicable documents, definitions, general and detailed requirements, notes, figures, and tables.
4. **Purpose and Application**: The purpose is to minimize ESD effects on parts, assemblies, and equipment, increasing reliability and decreasing maintenance and costs. The standard applies to government activities and contractors.
5. **Applicable Documents**: The standard lists government documents, specifications, standards, and handbooks that are part of this document.

The document also provides a table of contents outlining specific sections and subsections related to ESD control program requirements.

structure.text:
MIL-STD-1686C
11.  SCOPE
1.1  Purpose.  The purpose of this standard is to establish
comprehensive requirements for an ESD control program to minimize
the effects of ESD on parts, assemblies, and equipment.  Aneffective ESD control program will increase reliability anddecrease both maintenance actions and lifetime costs.  Thisstandard shall be tailored for various types of acquisitions.
1.2  Scope.  This standard defines the performance
requirements for an ESD control program for electrical and
electronic parts, assemblies, and equipment, susceptible todamage from ESD.  Electrically initiated explosive devices andpart level design are excluded from these requirements.  Thisstandard covers identification, testing, classification, assemblyand equipment design criteria, protected areas, handlingprocedures, training, marking of hardware, protective coveringand packaging, and provides for quality assurance requirements,audits and reviews.
1.3  Application.  This standard shall apply to Government
activities and contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, and
vendors.  When this standard is applied to Government activitiesthe term "contractor" shall be replaced with "Governmentactivity" as appropriate.
2.  APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS
2.1  General.  The documents listed in this section are
specified in sections 3,4, and 5 of this standard.  This section
does not include documents cited in other sections of thisstandard or recommended for additional information or asexamples.  While every effort has been made to ensure thecompleteness of this list, document users are cautioned that theymust meet all specified requirements documents cited in sections3,4, and 5 of this standard, whether or not they are listed.
2.2  Government documents.
2.2.1  Specifications, standards, and handbooks.  The
following standards and handbook form a part of this document to
the extent specified herein.  Unless otherwise specified, theissues of these documents are those listed in the issue of theDepartment of Defense Index of Specifications and Standards
structure.summary:
The partial document outlines the initial sections of the MIL-STD-1686C standard, focusing on establishing an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) control program. Key points include:

1. **Purpose**: The standard aims to minimize ESD effects on parts, assemblies, and equipment to enhance reliability and reduce maintenance and lifetime costs.
2. **Scope**: It defines performance requirements for ESD control for electrical and electronic components, excluding electrically initiated explosive devices and part level design. The standard covers various aspects such as identification, testing, classification, design criteria, handling procedures, training, marking, protective covering, packaging, and quality assurance.
3. **Application**: The standard applies to government activities, contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, and vendors.
4. **Applicable Documents**: Lists specific documents relevant to sections 3, 4, and 5 of the standard, emphasizing the need to meet all specified requirements.

75.2  Classification of ESDS parts, assemblies and equipment.
ESDS classification data shall be used to ensure that the ESD
control program (see 5.1), design hardening (see 5.2.2),protected areas (see 5.3), and handling procedures (see 5.4)provide the requisite levels of ESD protection in accordance withthe requirements of this standard.  Full characterization of theESD susceptibility of a part is accomplished by classification tothree defined models: the Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model(MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM).  The HBM, MM, and CDMsensitivity classification of parts shall be in accordance withtables I and II.  The HBM, MM, and CDM voltage levels do notcorrelate with each other.
TABLE I.  Classes of ESDS parts.

RANGE)
HBM   1     (>0V-1,999V)
  2  (2,000V-3,999V)  3 (4,000V-15,999V)

   M2     (101V-200V)    M3     (201V-400V)    M4     (401V-800V)    M5        (> 800V) 
CDM   C1       (0V-124V)
  C2     (125V-249V)  C3     (250V-499V)  C4     (500V-999V)  C5 (1,000V-1,499V)  C6 (1,500V-2,999V)  C7      (> 3,000V)

nodes.summary:
The partial document outlines specifications from MIL-STD-1686C, focusing on definitions, general requirements, and detailed requirements for an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) control program. Key points include:

1. **Definitions**: Terms not defined in the document should refer to MIL-HDBK-263.
2. **General Requirements**:
   - Contractors must establish, implement, and document an ESD control program.
   - The program must be applied to subcontractors, suppliers, and vendors.
   - Guidance for the program is provided in MIL-HDBK-263.
   - The standard can be tailored for specific acquisitions, subject to approval.
3. **Detailed Requirements**:
   - Contractors must prepare an ESD control program plan addressing all elements shown in a tailoring flow chart.
   - Subcontractors must also implement an ESD control program, with tailoring managed by the prime contractor.
   - ESDS parts, assemblies, and equipment must be classified based on their ESD susceptibility using the Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model (MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM).
   - Classification tables for HBM, MM, and CDM voltage levels are provided.

nodes.title: Classification of ESDS parts, assemblies and equipment
Part ESD sensitivity classes and classification
HBM sensitivity classification
nodes.text:
MIL-STD-1686C
8TABLE II. ESD test standards/methods for
         classification of ESDS parts.
ESD MODEL ESD TEST STANDARD/METHOD
HBM   EOS/ESD-S5.1
  MIL-STD-883 Method 3015  MIL-STD-750 Method 1020
MM     ESD-S5.2
CDM     ESD-S5.3
5.2.1  Part ESD sensitivity classes and classification. 
5.2.1.1  HBM sensitivity classification.  The principal
source of ESD damage is the human body, as modeled by the HBM
standards.  HBM ESD sensitivity classification of parts shall bedetermined as follows:
(a)  At the discretion of the contractor, all parts
shall be considered as HBM ESD sensitive.  In this case, allparts may be classified as falling in the HBM Class 1-3 voltageranges and included in the ESD control program.  If thecontractor has definitive data for the specific part (RAC VZAP-95data, Qualified Products List (QPL), Qualified Manufacturer List(QML), or manufacturers' data sheets), indicating it is notwithin HBM Classes 1-3, ESD controls are not required for thatpart.
(b)  At the discretion of the contractor, precise HBM
ESD sensitivity data, in accordance with the HBM test methodsspecified in tables I and II may be used to classify all parts.The three HBM test methods listed in table II may be consideredto be equivalent.  The preferred test method is EOS/ESD-S5.1.
5.2.1.2  MM sensitivity classification.  The prime source of
damage for the MM is a charged machine or device.  MM ESD

nodes.text:
MIL-STD-1686C
8TABLE II. ESD test standards/methods for
         classification of ESDS parts.

HBM   EOS/ESD-S5.1
  MIL-STD-883 Method 3015  MIL-STD-750 Method 1020
MM     ESD-S5.2
CDM     ESD-S5.3
5.2.1  Part ESD sensitivity classes and classification. 
5.2.1.1  HBM sensitivity classification.  The principal
source of ESD damage is the human body, as modeled by the HBM
standards.  HBM ESD sensitivity classification of parts shall bedetermined as follows:
(a)  At the discretion of the contractor, all parts
shall be considered as HBM ESD sensitive.  In this case, allparts may be classified as falling in the HBM Class 1-3 voltageranges and included in the ESD control program.  If thecontractor has definitive data for the specific part (RAC VZAP-95data, Qualified Products List (QPL), Qualified Manufacturer List(QML), or manufacturers' data sheets), indicating it is notwithin HBM Classes 1-3, ESD controls are not required for thatpart.
(b)  At the discretion of the contractor, precise HBM
ESD sensitivity data, in accordance with the HBM test methodsspecified in tables I and II may be used to classify all parts.The three HBM test methods listed in table II may be consideredto be equivalent.  The preferred test method is EOS/ESD-S5.1.
5.2.1.2  MM sensitivity classification.  The prime source of
damage for the MM is a charged machine or device.  MM ESD
sensitivity classification for parts should be determined by, andat the discretion of, the contractor.  The contractor shallconsider the applicability of MM ESD part sensitivity data basedupon the type of work performed.MIL-STD-1686C
95.2.1.3  CDM sensitivity classification.  The prime source
of damage for the CDM is the rapid discharge of a charged part. 
This ESD event is totally part-dependent.  CDM ESD sensitivityclassification for parts should be determined by, and at thediscretion of, the contractor. The contractor shall consider theapplicability of CDM ESD part sensitivity data based upon thetype of work performed.
5.2.2  Assembly/equipment classification and design
hardening.  When an assembly or equipment incorporates protective
circuitry or techniques to meet the minimum design hardening
requirements of this standard, the assembly or equipment isclassified at the design-hardened ESD withstand voltage level. Classification of assemblies or equipment meeting the designhardening requirements (see table III) should be based uponanalytical techniques, or actual test as specified in 5.2.2.1through 5.2.2.3.
5.2.2.1  Direct contact, non-operating assembly, 2,000 V
body/finger or hand/metal HBM tests.  This model can be used to
verify that assemblies will not be damaged during non-operating
conditions, by direct contact (2,000 V body/finger or hand/metalHBM) to input, output, and interface connections.  This threatoccurs during the maintenance process when assemblies are handledwithout their associated cables and connectors attached.  Thisthreat applies to all types of assemblies.  The test for thismodel should consist of three positive and three negative pulsesat 2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal HBM, applied to each input,output, and interface connection of the assembly.  Therecommended test method for this model is IEEE STD C62.38-1994(see table IV)that provides guidance to determine which of thetwo ESD test methods (body/finger or hand/metal) is appropriatefor a specific assembly.
5.2.2.2  Direct contact, operating equipment, 4,000 V
hand/metal HBM test.  This model can be used to verify that
operating equipment will not be damaged (or non-recoverable
faults will not be injected), by direct contact (4,000 Vhand/metal HBM) to operator accessible points and exposed surfaceareas during the normal maintenance process.  This threat islimited to equipments subject to operator adjustments ormaintenance activities during operation.  The test for this modelshould consist of multiple pulses (the number is statisticallybased, in accordance with ANSI C63.16-1993) at 4,000 V hand/metalHBM, applied to each operator-accessible control and to the
nodes.summary:
The partial document discusses standards and methods for Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) testing and classification of ESD sensitive (ESDS) parts, as outlined in MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include:

1. **ESD Test Standards/Methods**: The document lists different ESD models (HBM, MM, CDM) and their corresponding test standards, such as EOS/ESD-S5.1 for HBM and ESD-S5.2 for MM.

2. **ESD Sensitivity Classes and Classification**:
   - **HBM Sensitivity Classification**: Parts can be classified as HBM ESD sensitive at the contractor's discretion. Precise HBM ESD sensitivity data may be used for classification.
   - **MM Sensitivity Classification**: Contractors determine MM ESD sensitivity based on the work performed.
   - **CDM Sensitivity Classification**: CDM ESD sensitivity is part-dependent and determined by the contractor.

3. **Assembly/Equipment Classification and Design Hardening**: The document outlines how assemblies or equipment incorporating protective circuitry are classified at the design-hardened ESD withstand voltage level. It specifies tests for direct contact in non-operating and operating conditions, including:
   - **2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal HBM tests** for non-operating assemblies.
   - **4,000 V hand/metal HBM test** for operating equipment to ensure no damage or non-recoverable faults during maintenance.

4. **Test Methods**: Recommended test methods include IEEE STD C62.38-1994 and ANSI C63.16-1993 for determining appropriate ESD test methods and statistical pulse application, respectively.

The partial document discusses standards for electrostatic discharge (ESD) protection, focusing on two main areas:

1. **CDM Sensitivity Classification**:
   - The primary cause of damage in the Charged Device Model (CDM) is the rapid discharge of a charged part, which is dependent on the specific part.
   - The contractor is responsible for determining and classifying CDM ESD sensitivity based on the type of work performed.

2. **Assembly/Equipment Classification and Design Hardening**:
   - Assemblies or equipment incorporating protective circuitry should meet minimum design hardening requirements and be classified at the design-hardened ESD withstand voltage level.
   - Classification methods include analytical techniques or actual tests specified in sections 5.2.2.1 through 5.2.2.3.
   - Specific tests include:
     - **5.2.2.1**: Direct contact, non-operating assembly tests using a 2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal Human Body Model (HBM) to ensure assemblies are not damaged during maintenance.
     - **5.2.2.2**: Direct contact, operating equipment tests using a 4,000 V hand/metal HBM to ensure operating equipment is not damaged or experiences non-recoverable faults during normal maintenance.

nodes.summary:
The partial document discusses standards for electrostatic discharge (ESD) protection and classification, specifically referencing MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include:

1. **CDM Sensitivity Classification**: The Charged Device Model (CDM) ESD sensitivity classification is determined by the contractor, considering the type of work performed and the applicability of CDM ESD part sensitivity data.

2. **Assembly/Equipment Classification and Design Hardening**: Assemblies or equipment incorporating protective circuitry are classified at the design-hardened ESD withstand voltage level. Classification methods include analytical techniques or actual tests specified in sections 5.2.2.1 through 5.2.2.3.

3. **Direct Contact, Non-Operating Assembly Test**: This test verifies that assemblies will not be damaged during non-operating conditions by direct contact (2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal HBM) to input, output, and interface connections. The test method follows IEEE STD C62.38-1994.

4. **Direct Contact, Operating Equipment Test**: This test ensures that operating equipment will not be damaged or experience non-recoverable faults by direct contact (4,000 V hand/metal HBM) to operator-accessible points and exposed surface areas during normal maintenance. The test method follows ANSI C63.16-1993.

The partial document discusses standards and procedures for electrostatic discharge (ESD) protection as outlined in MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include:

1. **CDM Sensitivity Classification**: The Charged Device Model (CDM) ESD sensitivity classification is determined by the contractor based on the type of work performed.

2. **Assembly/Equipment Classification and Design Hardening**:
   - **Direct Contact, Non-Operating Assembly**: Tests involve 2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal Human Body Model (HBM) to ensure assemblies are not damaged during maintenance.

   - **Indirect Contact, Operating Equipment**: Tests involve 4,000 V Furniture Model to ensure digital equipment in office environments is not damaged by indirect contact.

3. **Protected Areas**: Handling of ESD-sensitive parts, assemblies, and equipment should be done in ESD-protected areas following specific procedures. If handling in protected areas is not feasible, alternative precautions must be taken to minimize electrostatic voltages and charges.

The document also references various test standards and methods, including IEEE STD C62.38-1994, ANSI C63.16-1993, and IEC 801-2, for ESD hardening of assemblies and equipment.

MIL-STD-1686C
75.2  Classification of ESDS parts, assemblies and equipment.
ESDS classification data shall be used to ensure that the ESD
control program (see 5.1), design hardening (see 5.2.2),protected areas (see 5.3), and handling procedures (see 5.4)provide the requisite levels of ESD protection in accordance withthe requirements of this standard.  Full characterization of theESD susceptibility of a part is accomplished by classification tothree defined models: the Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model(MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM).  The HBM, MM, and CDMsensitivity classification of parts shall be in accordance withtables I and II.  The HBM, MM, and CDM voltage levels do notcorrelate with each other.

  C2     (125V-249V)  C3     (250V-499V)  C4     (500V-999V)  C5 (1,000V-1,499V)  C6 (1,500V-2,999V)  C7      (> 3,000V)
NOTE: The above Classes may be dividedinto subclasses.MIL-STD-1686C

(a)  At the discretion of the contractor, all parts
shall be considered as HBM ESD sensitive.  In this case, allparts may be classified as falling in the HBM Class 1-3 voltageranges and included in the ESD control program.  If thecontractor has definitive data for the specific part (RAC VZAP-95data, Qualified Products List (QPL), Qualified Manufacturer List(QML), or manufacturers' data sheets), indicating it is notwithin HBM Classes 1-3, ESD controls are not required for thatpart.
(b)  At the discretion of the contractor, precise HBM
ESD sensitivity data, in accordance with the HBM test methodsspecified in tables I and II may be used to classify all parts.The three HBM test methods listed in table II may be consideredto be equivalent.  The preferred test method is EOS/ESD-S5.1.
5.2.1.2  MM sensitivity classification.  The prime source of
damage for the MM is a charged machine or device.  MM ESD
sensitivity classification for parts should be determined by, andat the discretion of, the contractor.  The contractor shallconsider the applicability of MM ESD part sensitivity data basedupon the type of work performed.
nodes.summary: The partial document discusses standards for Electrostatic Discharge Sensitive (ESDS) parts, assemblies, and equipment as outlined in MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include the classification of ESDS parts based on their susceptibility to ESD, using three models: Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model (MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM). The document provides voltage ranges for each model's classes and specifies test standards/methods for classification. It also details procedures for determining HBM and MM sensitivity classifications, emphasizing the contractor's discretion in using available data or performing precise ESD sensitivity tests.

nodes.title: Protected areas
nodes.text:
MIL-STD-1686C
11TABLE IV. ESD test standards/methods for hardening of 
ESDS assembly/equipment.
ESD MODEL ESD TEST
STANDARD/METHOD
Body/Finger or
Hand/Metal HBMIEEE STD C62.38-
1994 (Assembly)
Hand/Metal HBM IEC 801-2(1)
ANSI C63.16-1993(Equipment)
Furniture Model ANSI C63.16-1993
(Equipment)
Note: (1) IEC 801-2 (First Edition,
1984) and IEC 801-2 (Second edition1991-04) are both in current use.
5.2.2.3  Indirect contact, operating equipment, 4,000 V
furniture model test.  This model can be used to verify that
operating digital equipment in an office environment will not be
damaged (or non-recoverable faults will not be injected), byindirect contact (4,000 V Furniture Model) during normalactivities performed within the proximity of the equipment.  Thisthreat applies to all digital equipment in an office environmentbut is especially important for NDI(Non-Developmental Item)/COTS(Commercial-Off-The-Shelf) equipment.  The test for this modelshould consist of multiple pulses (the number is statisticallybased, in accordance with ANSI C63.16-1993) using the 4,000 VFurniture Model, applied to a Horizontal Coupling Plane (HCP) ora Vertical Coupling Plane (VCP).  The HCP is preferred.  Therecommended test method is in ANSI C63.16-1993 (See table IV).
5.3  Protected areas.  Handling of ESDS parts, assemblies
and equipment without ESD protective covering or packaging shall
be performed in ESD protected areas in accordance with ESDprotective handling procedures (see 5.4).  If there are practicalconsiderations which preclude handling in the protected areas, alternative handling precautions and procedures shall be preparedand utilized in the unprotected areas. Electrostatic voltages andcharges generated in areas where ESDS parts, assemblies andequipment are handled without protective covering or packagingshall be minimized to the lowest practicable level.MIL-STD-1686C
125.4  Handling procedures.  ESD protective handling
procedures shall be established, documented, and implemented. 
Handling procedures shall include, as applicable, ESD damageprevention procedures to be used in all areas where ESDS itemsare manually or machine processed.
5.5  Protective covering.  When not being worked on or when
outside protected areas, ESDS parts and assemblies shall be
enclosed in ESD protective covering or packaging.  Protectivepackaging of ESDS items shall be in accordance with 5.8. Guidancerelated to protective covering is provided in MIL-HDBK-263.
5.6  Training.  Periodic and recurrent ESD training shall be
provided to all personnel who perform or supervise any of the
work associated with ESDS items.  Training may be classroomtraining, on the job instruction, or a combination of both.
5.7  Marking of hardware.  Marking shall be as specified in
the following:
5.7.1  Assemblies.  ESDS assemblies shall be marked with the
EIA RS-471 symbol as illustrated in figure 2.  The symbol shall
be located in a position readily visible to personnel when theassembly is incorporated in its next higher assembly.  Whenphysical size or orientation of the assembly precludes compliancewith this requirement, alternative marking procedures shall bedeveloped and implemented only with prior concurrence by theacquiring activity.
(RS-471)
FIGURE 2. Electrostatic discharge symbol.
nodes.summary:
The partial document discusses standards and procedures for Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) protection and testing, particularly focusing on the following main points:

1. **ESD Test Standards/Methods**: The document lists various ESD test standards and methods for different models, such as Body/Finger or Hand/Metal and Furniture Model, referencing standards like IEEE STD C62.38-1994, IEC 801-2, and ANSI C63.16-1993.

2. **Indirect Contact Testing**: It describes the indirect contact test using the Furniture Model at 4,000 V to ensure digital equipment in an office environment is not damaged by indirect contact during normal activities.

3. **Protected Areas**: The document outlines the handling of ESDS (Electrostatic Discharge Sensitive) parts, assemblies, and equipment in ESD protected areas to minimize electrostatic voltages and charges.

4. **Handling Procedures**: It emphasizes the need for established, documented, and implemented ESD protective handling procedures.

5. **Protective Covering**: The document specifies that ESDS parts and assemblies should be enclosed in ESD protective covering or packaging when not being worked on or when outside protected areas.

6. **Training**: It mandates periodic and recurrent ESD training for all personnel involved with ESDS items.

7. **Marking of Hardware**: The document details the marking requirements for ESDS assemblies, including the use of the EIA RS-471 symbol.

MIL-STD-1686C
125.4  Handling procedures.  ESD protective handling
procedures shall be established, documented, and implemented. 
Handling procedures shall include, as applicable, ESD damageprevention procedures to be used in all areas where ESDS itemsare manually or machine processed.
5.5  Protective covering.  When not being worked on or when
outside protected areas, ESDS parts and assemblies shall be
enclosed in ESD protective covering or packaging.  Protectivepackaging of ESDS items shall be in accordance with 5.8. Guidancerelated to protective covering is provided in MIL-HDBK-263.
5.6  Training.  Periodic and recurrent ESD training shall be
provided to all personnel who perform or supervise any of the
work associated with ESDS items.  Training may be classroomtraining, on the job instruction, or a combination of both.
5.7  Marking of hardware.  Marking shall be as specified in
the following:
5.7.1  Assemblies.  ESDS assemblies shall be marked with the
EIA RS-471 symbol as illustrated in figure 2.  The symbol shall
be located in a position readily visible to personnel when theassembly is incorporated in its next higher assembly.  Whenphysical size or orientation of the assembly precludes compliancewith this requirement, alternative marking procedures shall bedeveloped and implemented only with prior concurrence by theacquiring activity.
(RS-471)
FIGURE 2. Electrostatic discharge symbol.MIL-STD-1686C
135.7.2  Equipment.  Equipment containing ESDS parts and
assemblies shall be marked with the EIA RS-471 symbol.  The
symbol shall be located on the exterior surface of the equipmentand readily visible to personnel prior to gaining access to ESDSparts and assemblies within the equipment.  The following ESDcaution statement should be placed adjacent to the RS-471 symbol:
"CAUTION
CONTAINS PARTS AND
ASSEMBLIES SUSCEPTIBLE TO DAMAGE BY
ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE (ESD)."
The symbol and caution statement shall conform to the labeling
requirements of ASTM F 1166.
5.8  Packaging.  ESD protective packaging will be in
accordance with the contract or purchase order for ESDS items. 
If ESD protective packaging is not specified in the contract orpurchase order, requirements for packaging will be in accordancewith MIL-STD-2073 codes GX, JK, JW, KB or KE for ESDS items.
5.9  Quality assurance reviews and audits.  The contractor 
should address ESD control in the planning and preparation
performed for quality assurance reviews and audits to ensure thatthese consistently address ESD control.  The contractor'sscheduled design, program reviews and audits should include ESDcontrol program requirements. 
5.10  Failure analysis.   Failure analysis, when performed,
should consider ESD related failure modes and effects as part of
the failure analysis.

(This section contains information of a general or explanatory
nature which may be helpful, but is not mandatory.)

establishing, documenting and implementing an ESD control
program.  For those contracts incorporating DOD-STD-1686 of 2 May1980, the companion document was DOD-HDBK-263 of 2 May 1980. structure.text:
MIL-STD-1686C
53.  DEFINITIONS
3.1  The definitions of terms not defined herein shall be in
accordance with MIL-HDBK-263.
4.  GENERAL REQUIREMENTS
4.1  General.  Contractors shall establish, implement, and
document the ESD control program in accordance with the
requirements of this standard.  Contractors shall also apply theESD control program requirements (see 5.1.1) to subcontractors,suppliers, and vendors to provide continuous protection for ESDSparts, assemblies and equipment.  Detailed guidance forestablishing, implementing, documenting, and auditing theelements of an ESD control program is provided in MIL-HDBK-263. 
4.1.1  Tailoring of this standard.  This standard, or
portions thereof, may not apply to all acquisitions or
applications.  The contractor shall tailor the ESD controlprogram for the acquisition by selecting the applicable elementsof figure 1.  The reference numbers in figure 1 are included forready reference to the appropriate sections of this standard. Figure 1 cannot, and does not take precedence over contractual,delivery order or this standard's requirements.  Tailoring issubject to approval by the acquiring activity.
5.  DETAILED REQUIREMENTS
5.1  ESD control program plan.  The contractor shall prepare
an ESD control program plan that addresses each of the elements
of the ESD control program shown in the tailoring flow chartdepicted in figure 1. The ESD control program plan is theprincipal document for designing, implementing, and auditing theESD control program. The goal is a fully implemented andintegrated ESD control program that conforms to the qualitysystem requirements.
5.1.1  Subcontractor control.  The contractor shall ensure
that subcontractors, suppliers and vendors have established and
implemented an ESD control program in accordance with therequirements of this standard.  Tailoring of this standard forsubcontractors, suppliers and vendors shall be the responsibilityof the prime contractor (see 4.1.1).
structure.summary: The partial document outlines specifications from MIL-STD-1686C, focusing on definitions, general requirements, and detailed requirements for an Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) control program. Key points include the need for contractors to establish, implement, and document an ESD control program, ensuring compliance from subcontractors, suppliers, and vendors. The document also discusses the tailoring of the standard to fit specific acquisitions and the preparation of an ESD control program plan. It emphasizes the importance of integrating the ESD control program with quality system requirements and ensuring subcontractors adhere to the same standards.

MIL-STD-1686C
135.7.2  Equipment.  Equipment containing ESDS parts and
assemblies shall be marked with the EIA RS-471 symbol.  The
symbol shall be located on the exterior surface of the equipmentand readily visible to personnel prior to gaining access to ESDSparts and assemblies within the equipment.  The following ESDcaution statement should be placed adjacent to the RS-471 symbol:
"CAUTION
CONTAINS PARTS AND
ASSEMBLIES SUSCEPTIBLE TO DAMAGE BY
ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE (ESD)."
The symbol and caution statement shall conform to the labeling
requirements of ASTM F 1166.
5.8  Packaging.  ESD protective packaging will be in
accordance with the contract or purchase order for ESDS items. 
If ESD protective packaging is not specified in the contract orpurchase order, requirements for packaging will be in accordancewith MIL-STD-2073 codes GX, JK, JW, KB or KE for ESDS items.

should address ESD control in the planning and preparation
performed for quality assurance reviews and audits to ensure thatthese consistently address ESD control.  The contractor'sscheduled design, program reviews and audits should include ESDcontrol program requirements. 
5.10  Failure analysis.   Failure analysis, when performed,
should consider ESD related failure modes and effects as part of
the failure analysis.

75.2  Classification of ESDS parts, assemblies and equipment.
ESDS classification data shall be used to ensure that the ESD
control program (see 5.1), design hardening (see 5.2.2),protected areas (see 5.3), and handling procedures (see 5.4)provide the requisite levels of ESD protection in accordance withthe requirements of this standard.  Full characterization of theESD susceptibility of a part is accomplished by classification tothree defined models: the Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model(MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM).  The HBM, MM, and CDMsensitivity classification of parts shall be in accordance withtables I and II.  The HBM, MM, and CDM voltage levels do notcorrelate with each other.
TABLE I.  Classes of ESDS parts.
ESD MODEL ESD CLASS (VOLTAGE
RANGE)
HBM   1     (>0V-1,999V)
  2  (2,000V-3,999V)  3 (4,000V-15,999V)
MM    M1       (0V-100V) 
   M2     (101V-200V)    M3     (201V-400V)    M4     (401V-800V)    M5        (> 800V) 
CDM   C1       (0V-124V)
  C2     (125V-249V)  C3     (250V-499V)  C4     (500V-999V)  C5 (1,000V-1,499V)  C6 (1,500V-2,999V)  C7      (> 3,000V)
NOTE: The above Classes may be dividedinto subclasses.MIL-STD-1686C
8TABLE II. ESD test standards/methods for
         classification of ESDS parts.
ESD MODEL ESD TEST STANDARD/METHOD
HBM   EOS/ESD-S5.1
  MIL-STD-883 Method 3015  MIL-STD-750 Method 1020
MM     ESD-S5.2
CDM     ESD-S5.3
5.2.1  Part ESD sensitivity classes and classification. 
5.2.1.1  HBM sensitivity classification.  The principal
source of ESD damage is the human body, as modeled by the HBM
standards.  HBM ESD sensitivity classification of parts shall bedetermined as follows:
(a)  At the discretion of the contractor, all parts
shall be considered as HBM ESD sensitive.  In this case, allparts may be classified as falling in the HBM Class 1-3 voltageranges and included in the ESD control program.  If thecontractor has definitive data for the specific part (RAC VZAP-95data, Qualified Products List (QPL), Qualified Manufacturer List(QML), or manufacturers' data sheets), indicating it is notwithin HBM Classes 1-3, ESD controls are not required for thatpart.
(b)  At the discretion of the contractor, precise HBM
ESD sensitivity data, in accordance with the HBM test methodsspecified in tables I and II may be used to classify all parts.The three HBM test methods listed in table II may be consideredto be equivalent.  The preferred test method is EOS/ESD-S5.1.
5.2.1.2  MM sensitivity classification.  The prime source of
damage for the MM is a charged machine or device.  MM ESD
sensitivity classification for parts should be determined by, andat the discretion of, the contractor.  The contractor shallconsider the applicability of MM ESD part sensitivity data basedupon the type of work performed.MIL-STD-1686C
95.2.1.3  CDM sensitivity classification.  The prime source
of damage for the CDM is the rapid discharge of a charged part. 
This ESD event is totally part-dependent.  CDM ESD sensitivityclassification for parts should be determined by, and at thediscretion of, the contractor. The contractor shall consider theapplicability of CDM ESD part sensitivity data based upon thetype of work performed.
5.2.2  Assembly/equipment classification and design
hardening.  When an assembly or equipment incorporates protective
circuitry or techniques to meet the minimum design hardening
requirements of this standard, the assembly or equipment isclassified at the design-hardened ESD withstand voltage level. Classification of assemblies or equipment meeting the designhardening requirements (see table III) should be based uponanalytical techniques, or actual test as specified in 5.2.2.1through 5.2.2.3.
5.2.2.1  Direct contact, non-operating assembly, 2,000 V
body/finger or hand/metal HBM tests.  This model can be used to
verify that assemblies will not be damaged during non-operating
conditions, by direct contact (2,000 V body/finger or hand/metalHBM) to input, output, and interface connections.  This threatoccurs during the maintenance process when assemblies are handledwithout their associated cables and connectors attached.  Thisthreat applies to all types of assemblies.  The test for thismodel should consist of three positive and three negative pulsesat 2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal HBM, applied to each input,output, and interface connection of the assembly.  Therecommended test method for this model is IEEE STD C62.38-1994(see table IV)that provides guidance to determine which of thetwo ESD test methods (body/finger or hand/metal) is appropriatefor a specific assembly.
5.2.2.2  Direct contact, operating equipment, 4,000 V
hand/metal HBM test.  This model can be used to verify that
operating equipment will not be damaged (or non-recoverable
faults will not be injected), by direct contact (4,000 Vhand/metal HBM) to operator accessible points and exposed surfaceareas during the normal maintenance process.  This threat islimited to equipments subject to operator adjustments ormaintenance activities during operation.  The test for this modelshould consist of multiple pulses (the number is statisticallybased, in accordance with ANSI C63.16-1993) at 4,000 V hand/metalHBM, applied to each operator-accessible control and to theMIL-STD-1686C

5.2.2.3  Indirect contact, operating equipment, 4,000 V
furniture model test.  This model can be used to verify that
operating digital equipment in an office environment will not be
damaged (or non-recoverable faults will not be injected), byindirect contact (4,000 V Furniture Model) during normalactivities performed within the proximity of the equipment.  Thisthreat applies to all digital equipment in an office environmentbut is especially important for NDI(Non-Developmental Item)/COTS(Commercial-Off-The-Shelf) equipment.  The test for this modelshould consist of multiple pulses (the number is statisticallybased, in accordance with ANSI C63.16-1993) using the 4,000 VFurniture Model, applied to a Horizontal Coupling Plane (HCP) ora Vertical Coupling Plane (VCP).  The HCP is preferred.  Therecommended test method is in ANSI C63.16-1993 (See table IV).
5.3  Protected areas.  Handling of ESDS parts, assemblies
and equipment without ESD protective covering or packaging shall
be performed in ESD protected areas in accordance with ESDprotective handling procedures (see 5.4).  If there are practicalconsiderations which preclude handling in the protected areas, alternative handling precautions and procedures shall be preparedand utilized in the unprotected areas. Electrostatic voltages andcharges generated in areas where ESDS parts, assemblies andequipment are handled without protective covering or packagingshall be minimized to the lowest practicable level.MIL-STD-1686C
125.4  Handling procedures.  ESD protective handling
procedures shall be established, documented, and implemented. 
Handling procedures shall include, as applicable, ESD damageprevention procedures to be used in all areas where ESDS itemsare manually or machine processed.
5.5  Protective covering.  When not being worked on or when
outside protected areas, ESDS parts and assemblies shall be
enclosed in ESD protective covering or packaging.  Protectivepackaging of ESDS items shall be in accordance with 5.8. Guidancerelated to protective covering is provided in MIL-HDBK-263.
5.6  Training.  Periodic and recurrent ESD training shall be
provided to all personnel who perform or supervise any of the
work associated with ESDS items.  Training may be classroomtraining, on the job instruction, or a combination of both.
5.7  Marking of hardware.  Marking shall be as specified in
the following:
5.7.1  Assemblies.  ESDS assemblies shall be marked with the
EIA RS-471 symbol as illustrated in figure 2.  The symbol shall
be located in a position readily visible to personnel when theassembly is incorporated in its next higher assembly.  Whenphysical size or orientation of the assembly precludes compliancewith this requirement, alternative marking procedures shall bedeveloped and implemented only with prior concurrence by theacquiring activity.
(RS-471)

structure.summary:
The partial document outlines specifications and procedures related to Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) control for parts, assemblies, and equipment. Key points include:

1. **Classification of ESDS Parts**: Parts are classified based on their ESD sensitivity using models like Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model (MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM).
2. **Design Hardening**: Guidelines for ensuring that assemblies and equipment meet ESD withstand voltage levels through protective circuitry or techniques.
3. **Protected Areas**: Procedures for handling ESDS parts in protected areas to minimize electrostatic voltages and charges.
4. **Handling Procedures**: Establishment of ESD protective handling procedures to prevent damage during manual or machine processing.
5. **Protective Covering**: Requirements for enclosing ESDS parts in protective covering or packaging when not in use or outside protected areas.
6. **Training**: Mandatory periodic training for personnel involved with ESDS items.
7. **Marking of Hardware**: Specific marking requirements for ESDS assemblies to ensure visibility and compliance.

The document also references various standards and methods for ESD testing and classification, such as MIL-STD-1686C, EOS/ESD-S5.1, and ANSI C63.16-1993.

structure.summary: The partial document discusses the process of photosynthesis, highlighting the role of chlorophyll in capturing light energy. It explains how plants convert this energy into chemical energy stored in glucose, with oxygen as a byproduct. The document also mentions the two stages of photosynthesis: the light-dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle. Additionally, it touches on the factors affecting the rate of photosynthesis, such as light intensity, temperature, and carbon dioxide concentration.

structure.summary:
The partial document discusses standards for Electrostatic Discharge Sensitivity (ESDS) as outlined in MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include:

1. **Classification of ESDS Parts**: The document specifies the classification of ESDS parts, assemblies, and equipment to ensure appropriate levels of ESD protection.
2. **ESD Models**: Three models are used for ESD susceptibility characterization: Human Body Model (HBM), Machine Model (MM), and Charged Device Model (CDM).

4. **HBM Sensitivity Classification**: Details on how to determine HBM ESD sensitivity, including the option for contractors to classify all parts as HBM ESD sensitive or use precise data.
5. **MM Sensitivity Classification**: Guidelines for determining MM ESD sensitivity, with discretion given to the contractor based on the type of work performed.

Therecommended test method for this model is IEEE STD C62.38-1994(see table IV)that provides guidance to determine which of thetwo ESD test methods (body/finger or hand/metal) is appropriatefor a specific assembly.
5.2.2.2  Direct contact, operating equipment, 4,000 V
hand/metal HBM test.  This model can be used to verify that
operating equipment will not be damaged (or non-recoverable
faults will not be injected), by direct contact (4,000 Vhand/metal HBM) to operator accessible points and exposed surfaceareas during the normal maintenance process.  This threat islimited to equipments subject to operator adjustments ormaintenance activities during operation.  The test for this modelshould consist of multiple pulses (the number is statisticallybased, in accordance with ANSI C63.16-1993) at 4,000 V hand/metalHBM, applied to each operator-accessible control and to theMIL-STD-1686C

structure.summary:
The partial document discusses standards and methods for Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) testing and classification of ESD sensitive (ESDS) parts, as outlined in MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include:

1. **ESD Test Standards/Methods**: The document lists different ESD models (HBM, MM, CDM) and their corresponding test standards, such as EOS/ESD-S5.1 for HBM and MIL-STD-883 Method 3015.

2. **ESD Sensitivity Classes and Classification**:
   - **HBM Sensitivity Classification**: Details how parts should be classified based on HBM ESD sensitivity, with options for contractors to classify all parts as sensitive or use precise data.
   - **MM Sensitivity Classification**: Addresses Machine Model (MM) ESD sensitivity, with classification determined by the contractor based on the type of work performed.
   - **CDM Sensitivity Classification**: Focuses on Charged Device Model (CDM) ESD sensitivity, which is part-dependent and determined by the contractor.

3. **Assembly/Equipment Classification and Design Hardening**:
   - **Direct Contact, Non-Operating Assembly**: Describes a 2,000 V body/finger or hand/metal HBM test to ensure assemblies are not damaged during non-operating conditions.
   - **Direct Contact, Operating Equipment**: Outlines a 4,000 V hand/metal HBM test to verify that operating equipment is not damaged during normal maintenance.
   - **Indirect Contact, Operating Furniture Model**: Mentions a test using a Horizontal Coupling Plane (HCP) or Vertical Coupling Plane (VCP) to simulate discharges to objects adjacent to the equipment.

4. **ESD Assembly/Equipment Design Hardening Goals**: Provides a table (Table III) listing ESD design hardening requirements for different test types and functional levels.

The HCP is preferred.  Therecommended test method is in ANSI C63.16-1993 (See table IV).
5.3  Protected areas.  Handling of ESDS parts, assemblies
and equipment without ESD protective covering or packaging shall
be performed in ESD protected areas in accordance with ESDprotective handling procedures (see 5.4).  If there are practicalconsiderations which preclude handling in the protected areas, alternative handling precautions and procedures shall be preparedand utilized in the unprotected areas. Electrostatic voltages andcharges generated in areas where ESDS parts, assemblies andequipment are handled without protective covering or packagingshall be minimized to the lowest practicable level.
structure.summary:
The partial document discusses standards and procedures for Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) protection in assembly and equipment design, particularly focusing on MIL-STD-1686C. Key points include:

1. **ESD Hardening Goals**:
   - **Direct Contact, Non-Operating**: 2,000 volts for all assemblies at inputs, outputs, and interface connections.
   - **Direct Contact, Operating**: 4,000 volts for operator-accessible controls and the center of each plane surface of field-maintained equipment.
   - **Indirect Contact, Operating**: 4,000 volts for digital office equipment using the Horizontal Coupling Plane (HCP) or Vertical Coupling Plane (VCP).

2. **ESD Test Standards/Methods**:
   - **Body/Finger or Hand/Metal HBM**: IEEE STD C62.38-1994 for assemblies and IEC 801-2 or ANSI C63.16-1993 for equipment.
   - **Furniture Model**: ANSI C63.16-1993 for equipment.

3. **Indirect Contact Testing**:
   - The 4,000 V Furniture Model test ensures that digital equipment in an office environment is not damaged by indirect contact during normal activities. This is crucial for Non-Developmental Item (NDI) and Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment.

4. **Protected Areas**:
   - Handling of ESD-sensitive (ESDS) parts, assemblies, and equipment without protective covering should be done in ESD-protected areas following specific handling procedures. If handling in protected areas is not feasible, alternative precautions must be taken to minimize electrostatic voltages and charges.

operating digital equipment in an office environment will not be

Thisthreat applies to all digital equipment in an office environmentbut is especially important for NDI(Non-Developmental Item)/COTS(Commercial-Off-The-Shelf) equipment.  The test for this modelshould consist of multiple pulses (the number is statisticallybased, in accordance with ANSI C63.16-1993) using the 4,000 VFurniture Model, applied to a Horizontal Coupling Plane (HCP) ora Vertical Coupling Plane (VCP).  The HCP is preferred.  Therecommended test method is in ANSI C63.16-1993 (See table IV).
5.3  Protected areas.  Handling of ESDS parts, assemblies
and equipment without ESD protective covering or packaging shall
be performed in ESD protected areas in accordance with ESDprotective handling procedures (see 5.4).  If there are practicalconsiderations which preclude handling in the protected areas, alternative handling precautions and procedures shall be preparedand utilized in the unprotected areas. Electrostatic voltages andcharges generated in areas where ESDS parts, assemblies andequipment are handled without protective covering or packagingshall be minimized to the lowest practicable level.MIL-STD-1686C
125.4  Handling procedures.  ESD protective handling
procedures shall be established, documented, and implemented. 
Handling procedures shall include, as applicable, ESD damageprevention procedures to be used in all areas where ESDS itemsare manually or machine processed.
5.5  Protective covering.  When not being worked on or when
outside protected areas, ESDS parts and assemblies shall be
enclosed in ESD protective covering or packaging.  Protectivepackaging of ESDS items shall be in accordance with 5.8. Guidancerelated to protective covering is provided in MIL-HDBK-263.
5.6  Training.  Periodic and recurrent ESD training shall be
provided to all personnel who perform or supervise any of the
work associated with ESDS items.  Training may be classroomtraining, on the job instruction, or a combination of both.
5.7  Marking of hardware.  Marking shall be as specified in
the following:
5.7.1  Assemblies.  ESDS assemblies shall be marked with the
EIA RS-471 symbol as illustrated in figure 2.  The symbol shall
be located in a position readily visible to personnel when theassembly is incorporated in its next higher assembly.  Whenphysical size or orientation of the assembly precludes compliancewith this requirement, alternative marking procedures shall bedeveloped and implemented only with prior concurrence by theacquiring activity.
(RS-471)
FIGURE 2. Electrostatic discharge symbol.MIL-STD-1686C
135.7.2  Equipment.  Equipment containing ESDS parts and
assemblies shall be marked with the EIA RS-471 symbol.  The
symbol shall be located on the exterior surface of the equipmentand readily visible to personnel prior to gaining access to ESDSparts and assemblies within the equipment.  The following ESDcaution statement should be placed adjacent to the RS-471 symbol:
"CAUTION
CONTAINS PARTS AND
ASSEMBLIES SUSCEPTIBLE TO DAMAGE BY
ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE (ESD)."
The symbol and caution statement shall conform to the labeling
requirements of ASTM F 1166.
5.8  Packaging.  ESD protective packaging will be in
accordance with the contract or purchase order for ESDS items. 
If ESD protective packaging is not specified in the contract orpurchase order, requirements for packaging will be in accordancewith MIL-STD-2073 codes GX, JK, JW, KB or KE for ESDS items.
5.9  Quality assurance reviews and audits.  The contractor 
should address ESD control in the planning and preparation
performed for quality assurance reviews and audits to ensure thatthese consistently address ESD control.  The contractor'sscheduled design, program reviews and audits should include ESDcontrol program requirements. 
5.10  Failure analysis.   Failure analysis, when performed,
should consider ESD related failure modes and effects as part of
the failure analysis.
6.  NOTES
(This section contains information of a general or explanatory
nature which may be helpful, but is not mandatory.)
6.1  Intended use.  This document provides requirements for
establishing, documenting and implementing an ESD control
program.  For those contracts incorporating DOD-STD-1686 of 2 May1980, the companion document was DOD-HDBK-263 of 2 May 1980.  Forthose contracts incorporating MIL-STD-1686A of 8 August 1988, thecompanion document was MIL-HDBK-263A of 22 February 1991. 14the companion document was MIL-HDBK-263B of 31 July 1994.  There
is no military handbook yet for this version of MIL-STD-1686C.
6.2  Issue of DoDISS.  When this standard is used in
acquisition, the applicable issue of the DoDISS must be cited in
the solicitation (see 2.1 and 2.2).

structure.summary:
The partial document outlines standards and procedures for Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) control to protect electrical and electronic parts, assemblies, and equipment. Key points include:

1. **ESD Test Standards/Methods**: Lists various ESD test standards and methods for hardening ESDS assemblies and equipment, including IEEE STD C62.38-1994, IEC 801-2, and ANSI C63.16-1993.

2. **Indirect Contact Testing**: Describes the Furniture Model test for verifying that operating digital equipment in an office environment will not be damaged by indirect contact ESD.

3. **Protected Areas**: Specifies that handling of ESDS parts without protective covering should be done in ESD protected areas, with procedures to minimize electrostatic voltages and charges.

4. **Handling Procedures**: Emphasizes the need for documented ESD protective handling procedures in all areas where ESDS items are processed.

5. **Protective Covering**: Requires ESDS parts and assemblies to be enclosed in protective covering or packaging when not being worked on or when outside protected areas.

6. **Training**: Mandates periodic ESD training for personnel handling ESDS items.

7. **Marking of Hardware**: Details the marking requirements for ESDS assemblies and equipment, including the use of the EIA RS-471 symbol and caution statements.

8. **Packaging**: Specifies ESD protective packaging requirements in accordance with contract specifications or MIL-STD-2073 codes.

9. **Quality Assurance and Failure Analysis**: Highlights the need for ESD control in quality assurance reviews and audits, and considering ESD-related failure modes in failure analysis.

10. **General Notes**: Provides explanatory information, including the intended use of the document and changes from previous issues.

11. **Standardization Document Improvement Proposal**: Includes instructions for recommending changes to the document.
